title: I like the idea of thornmail changes but I don't like the idea of grevious wounds
body:
Because grevious wounds shuts down lifesteal on more than just ranged ADCs. And armor stacking is already a really efficient way to reduce lifesteal tanking because lifesteal applies after damage reduction (or whatever order it applies in to significantly weaken LS but I believe it's after damage reduced). I think this keeps the same bland problem thornmail has now that makes it really underwhelming. Sure you get 100 armor but you get no HP and in the long run, there are far better options for tanking than 100 armor/no HP. And the passive now or a grevious wounds passive would feel pretty underwhelming for such a stat.

Many champions kinda have LS as an identity to their kits that aren't ADCs and an item like this would be really punishing to them, I'd say unfairly so. 

I would like to see the item gain more interesting gameplay while having moments of vulnerability and moments of clear strength. As an example, I'd say after being auto attacked or taking any physical damage in a certain duration, the item begins to store that energy and reflect it back in damage after a certain threshold on-hit to anyone who auto attacks the thornmail holder (think of the mirror shield in Zelda OOT when fighting the witches). 

There would be a clear glow or shine to the champion when the reflection is ready to pop and start returning a lot of damage and then this goes on cooldown for 60-70 seconds (almost like an AD hexdrinker/maw). This means if you want to continue focusing the tank, it comes with penalties but it also means focusing the tank isn't instant damage taken, which made it a frustrating item to deal with during cinderhulk meta. And if you elect not to focus the tank, the tank gets longer duration of life and longer zone control but in every situation, the item rewards proper gameplay rather than just being a punishment for focusing the champion with it or a punishment to the champion wasting 2300 gold on it when it's weak.

Just my two cents, and even then I'd rather not spend my last two pennies on the current thornmail. There's this grocery store by me that has a mechanical pony and rides only cost a penny, I'd rather take two rides on that and bust jewels.

You're asking why a magical item produces magical damage to people that attack the person wearing it?
Most magic has a range or else all skills in this game would be global.  If this were a game where range wasn't a primary factor, I wouldn't mind, but it is.

The main problem with Thronmail is that it isn't *actually* a tank item.  It's a soak item like Warmog's.  And it isn't a particularly good soak item, either.

Tank items make the user more of a threat to the enemy team.  They can do this with damage (Sunfire) with nerf-auras (Frozen Heart) or with crowd control (Mallet, Omen, ect).  By making the wearer more of a threat, a well made tank item encourages the enemy team to focus them to get rid of the disruptive presence.  But Thornmail doesn't make the wearer more of a threat.  In fact, it actively *discourages* the enemy team from focusing the user.

A passive like Thornmail's would, in fact, make quite a bit more sense on an IAS/Armor bruiser item than it does on a pure armor item.  Something like {{item:1029}} {{item:1031}} {{item:1043}}.  Some OnHit magic damage coupled with some %damage return.  As an added bonus, it would have innate synergy with Wit's magic resist shredding.

If you wanted a damage return effect that's fitting for an ACTUAL tank item, you would and something like:
**Unique Active Retribution:** Target an enemy champion to leash them.  So long as the enemy champion remains within range and/or you remain alive (percentage) of the damage the target enemy champion deals to champions is returned to them as magic damage.

THAT would encourage then enemy team to focus the Tank.

Sure you can.  We're doing it right now.

My premise here is pretty simple:  A tank item that encourages the enemy team to focus the tank is a well made tank item.  A tank item that *discourages* the enemy team to focus the tank is a bad tank item.  It is, in fact, doing the opposite of what a tank item is intended for.  Such an item is more at home on champions who want to discourage focus.

And before Riot gutted Thronmail, that's more or less what it was used for.  A single armor item picked up to round out defense on champs who need a balance of offense and defense.  Thornmail, in its present form, is fundamentally flawed.  There's a reason why it's a terrible niche item.

Frozen Heart is, in my eyes at least, a pretty ideal tank item.  The mana and CDR helps the Tank make better use of their abilities to make themselves a threat.  Further, the attack speed nerf aura helps them protect their nearby allies simply by existing.  Both of those factors increase the threat of the Frozen Heart user.

Less so with Omen, but that slow is nothing to sneeze at.  Omen is more of a soak/initiation item like Dead Man's, at least in my opinion.

But what about Thornmail?  How does it increase the user's threat?  Well, unless you scale off armor or have some way to force your foe to auto-attack you it really doesn't?  I mean, of course someone is going to attack that Shen sitting on their face.  But one way or the other, Thornmail exists to help people win duels, not be a better Tank.  And if we want Thorn to be a better armor item for tanky folks looking to improve their ability to duel auto-attack focused champions it seems to me that there are better ways to do it.

I guess my underlying thought is that Thorn should increase the user's threat even when they *aren't* being attacked.

That's entirely why the armor based scaling was added to the passive in the first place. Previously you could just pick it up and reflect 30% of auto attack damage taken and not care.

I'll state the unpopular opinion again:

Thornmail is a poor design type because it punishes a class of champs for playing correctly.  No, armor doesn't _punish_ champs who do physical damage, it is a healthy counterstat that allows you to mitigate their damage.  Armor penetration isn't _punishing_ tanks for the same reason.  It's easy to hate on ADCs, but imagine if items punished other classes for doing their jobs - thornmail for spells, maybe a bloodseeker-like effect that causes damage to champs who use mobility spells, an item that causes heals and shields to also damage the champ who casts them?

Even if you disagree with me about damage return, this is all still missing the obvious point that lifesteal should be nerfed instead of creating some terrible woman-who-swallowed-a-fly chain of itemization.  Why should ADC lifesteal be balanced around forcing tanks to build thornmail?  Why should all other sustain champs get screwed by the grievous wounds you'd put on that thornmail?  Do you really think a Nami or Sona needs even more things that crap on their heals?
